channel.title: Comments on: Why we don’t need journal blacklists

item.title: By: Around the Web: A quick list of readings on "predatory" open access journals – Confessions of a Science Librarian

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/why-we-dont-need-journal-blacklists/#comment-2697">Jaime A. Teixeira da Silva</a>.
Thanks for the ReadCube link. I also don't have a ResearchGate account because reasons http://fossilsandshit.com/illegal-file-hosting-site-researchgate-acquires-massive-financial-investment/
The journal allows you to upload the AAM/postprint with zero embargo :) http://www.sherpa.ac.uk/romeo/search.php?issn=1353-3452

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/why-we-dont-need-journal-blacklists/#comment-2694">Jaime A. Teixeira da Silva</a>.
Oh, could you also archive a version of your paper to make it freely available please? I don't have access, and can't see one via Unpaywall! :)

In reply to Jaime A. Teixeira da Silva.

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/why-we-dont-need-journal-blacklists/#comment-2694">Jaime A. Teixeira da Silva</a>.
Great points, thank you Jaime! I'll read your paper too, that looks interesting.
It seems the new list is essentially paywalled too, fancy that. http://www.nature.com/news/pay-to-view-blacklist-of-predatory-journals-set-to-launch-1.22090?WT.mc_id=TWT_NatureNews&sf83795942=1 If the list is designed to protect authors from the Global Souths, who are more prone to falling victim to predatory publishers, I don't see how this helps.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Jaime A. Teixeira da Silva.

Great points, thank you Jaime! I’ll read your paper too, that looks interesting.

It seems the new list is essentially paywalled too, fancy that. http://www.nature.com/news/pay-to-view-blacklist-of-predatory-journals-set-to-launch-1.22090?WT.mc_id=TWT_NatureNews&sf83795942=1 If the list is designed to protect authors from the Global Souths, who are more prone to falling victim to predatory publishers, I don’t see how this helps.

item.title: By: Jaime A. Teixeira da Silva
item.dc:creator: Jaime A. Teixeira da Silva
item.description:
Some valid commentary and discussion! Indeed, Beall has been opaque about his blog's closure [1], and the internet archive is not a suitable substitute. He raised awareness, but was so determined to "grow" his lists, that he failed to see that his criteria and their application in any consistent manner were a failure. So, it is not surprising if one or more entities listed sued him. The fact that Cabell's has confirmed that Beall has worked on the new "blacklist" as a "consultant" is troubling. In fact, Cabell has Tweeted conflicting and contradictory information, immediately reducing trust in its new commercial venture. The DOAJ list is also far from perfect. There is still alot of "junk" on there, but it seems to be the "whitest" of white lists among OA journals at the moment. I agree that transparency is key in the success of this new "blacklist". Beall only achieved fame because his blog was open, for all to read and interpret freely, as academics do. But if Cabell makes their list - and even more importantly their selection criteria which I think are based on 65 criteria, "smelling" like a renovated Beall's list - then this is bad news, because it means that the list, and its criteria, are hidden. As bad as the opaque impact factor, and as opaque as the sell-out Publons will become.
[1] Teixeira da Silva, J.A. (2017) The ethical and academic implications of the Jeffrey Beall (www.scholarlyoa.com) blog shutdown. Science and Engineering Ethics (in press) https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11948-017-9905-3 DOI: 10.1007/s11948-017-9905-3
item.content:encoded:
Some valid commentary and discussion! Indeed, Beall has been opaque about his blog’s closure [1], and the internet archive is not a suitable substitute. He raised awareness, but was so determined to “grow” his lists, that he failed to see that his criteria and their application in any consistent manner were a failure. So, it is not surprising if one or more entities listed sued him. The fact that Cabell’s has confirmed that Beall has worked on the new “blacklist” as a “consultant” is troubling. In fact, Cabell has Tweeted conflicting and contradictory information, immediately reducing trust in its new commercial venture. The DOAJ list is also far from perfect. There is still alot of “junk” on there, but it seems to be the “whitest” of white lists among OA journals at the moment. I agree that transparency is key in the success of this new “blacklist”. Beall only achieved fame because his blog was open, for all to read and interpret freely, as academics do. But if Cabell makes their list – and even more importantly their selection criteria which I think are based on 65 criteria, “smelling” like a renovated Beall’s list – then this is bad news, because it means that the list, and its criteria, are hidden. As bad as the opaque impact factor, and as opaque as the sell-out Publons will become.

[1] Teixeira da Silva, J.A. (2017) The ethical and academic implications of the Jeffrey Beall (www.scholarlyoa.com) blog shutdown. Science and Engineering Ethics (in press)
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11948-017-9905-3
DOI: 10.1007/s11948-017-9905-3
